instruction: Make a list of desirable Skills for software engineers to add to LinkedIn.
output:
Nontechnical Skills for Software Engineers to Add to Their Resumes
While technical skills are an obvious part of a software engineer’s resume, nontechnical skills can be just as valuable. Employers often look for software engineers who have experience in teamwork and leadership, communication, and problem-solving—all of which can be demonstrated through examples on your resume. Additionally, soft skills that demonstrate your ability to work well with others, such as empathy and emotional intelligence, can help you stand out from other applicants. Finally, any experience you have with project management or customer service can also be valuable additions to your resume.

instruction: We need to write a thematic tweet to share company news and facts. Please take a careful look at the facts and details provided and create a tweet based on them.
input:
- news: Applications for summer internships are open now
- Start with a thematic tie-in to Halloween
output:
, such as "Spotlight on #Halloween Startups: Meet the Entrepreneurs Behind the Scenes" or "Boo-tiful Businesses: The Spooky Side of Entrepreneurship."
- Use scary and exciting language to describe the company's products/services, such as "Terrifyingly Innovative: Our New Product Will Send Chills Down Your Spine!" or "Unlock the Secrets to Unlock Your Future with Our Cutting-Edge Services!"
- Include a statistic that showcases the company's success, such as "Did you know we've had 100% customer satisfaction for the past 5 years?" or "Our products have been featured in major publications like Forbes, The New York Times, and TechCrunch."
- Use the word "exciting" to describe the company's news, such as "We're excited to announce our new partnership with (company)!" or "Join us in this exciting journey as we continue to innovate in the (industry) space."
- End with a call-to-action, such as "Apply now for our summer internship program and join our team of talented individuals!" or "Keep up with our latest news and updates by following us on social media."

instruction: A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.
input:
Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output: but not required.

instruction: You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.
input:
Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.

instruction: Write a short analysis of the cinematography in the movie.
output:
(1989) is a film that explores the power of poetry and individuality through the eyes of an English teacher, Mr. Keating (Robin Williams). The cinematography in the film helps to create a sense of tension, release, and emotion that accompanies the characters’ journey.
The opening shots of the film are a bustling street in Boston, where we see Keating riding his bike towards the camera. This establishes a sense of freedom and energy that will become a recurring motif throughout the film. As Keating enters the school, the camera pans up to reveal the towering buildings, creating a feeling of confinement and restriction. This will be contrasted with the openness of nature, which will be used as a metaphor for freedom and creativity.
Throughout the film, there are numerous scenes of Keating leading his students outside to explore the natural world around them. The camera often maintains a wide angle, allowing us to take in the beauty of the landscape and the joy of discovery. These shots are often intercut with close-ups of the students’ faces, revealing their wonder and excitement.
As the film progresses, the cinematography becomes more dramatic, reflecting the increasing tension between Keating and the school administration. There are several scenes of Keating chalking poems on the blackboard, which are shot from low angles to convey a sense of power and authority. Similarly, when Keating stands up to the administration, the camera often shoots him from below, making him look larger and more intimidating.
The final scene of the film is perhaps the most iconic and well-known. As Keating delivers his famous “carpe diem” speech, the camera pans up from the students to the sky, where we see the words “O Captain! My Captain!” project

instruction: Please let me know your thoughts on the given place and why you think it deserves to be visited.
output:
: Barcelona is a vibrant city with stunning architecture, delicious cuisine, and great nightlife. The Sagrada Familia church, Picasso Museum, and La Rambla street are all must-see attractions.
Paris, France: Paris is the city of love and romance. The Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, and Arc de Triomphe are all iconic landmarks that you can't miss when visiting the city.
Rome, Italy: Rome is a city full of history and culture. The Colosseum, Vatican City, and Pantheon are all top attractions to check out when in Rome.
Amsterdam, Netherlands: Amsterdam is known for its canals, bicycles, and coffeeshops. The Anne Frank House, Van Gogh Museum, and Red Light District are all popular attractions.
Tokyo, Japan: Tokyo is a modern city with ancient traditions. The Tokyo Tower, Senso-ji Temple, and Imperial Palace are all must-see attractions.
Bangkok, Thailand: Bangkok is a city of contrasts, with skyscrapers, markets, and temples. The Grand Palace, Wat Arun, and Chatuchak Weekend Market are all worth visiting.
Venice, Italy: Venice is a city built on water, with canals, bridges, and gondolas. The St. Mark's Basilica, Doge's Palace, and Rialto Bridge are all must-see attractions.

instruction: Consider the best time of year to visit the given city, and provide your reasons for choosing that time.
output: : I would recommend visiting Sydney during the summer months of December to February. The weather is warm and sunny, with an average temperature of around 75-80 degrees Fahrenheit. This is also the peak tourist season in Sydney, so you'll find a wide range of activities and events happening throughout the city. The beaches are beautifully warm and inviting, and there are plenty of outdoor festivals and concerts to enjoy. Additionally, the New Year's Eve fireworks display over Sydney Harbour is a must-see event that draws millions of visitors each year.

instruction: Make a questionnaire to help hotel guests write hotel reviews.
output:
So for example, if the hotel has a pool, ask questions about how clean the pool was, how warm the water was, and whether there were enough lounges or towels available. If the hotel has a restaurant, ask about the quality of the food, the level of service, and whether the prices were reasonable. By gathering this information, you can create a more comprehensive review that will be helpful to other potential guests.
2. Be honest and constructive..
Be honest in your assessment of the hotel, but also be constructive. Criticize the hotel if necessary, but do so in a respectful and objective manner. Avoid making personal attacks on the staff or management, and focus on providing actionable feedback that can help improve the overall guest experience. This will show that you are a thoughtful and considerate reviewer, and your criticism will be taken more seriously.
3. Follow the guidelines set by the review platform..
Different review platforms have their own rules and guidelines for what kind of content is appropriate. For example, some platforms may not allow reviews that contain profanity or personal attacks. Make sure you familiarize yourself with the guidelines for each platform you plan to use, and adhere to them at all times. This will ensure that your review is published and that you don't risk getting banned from the platform.
4. Use specific examples to back up your claims..
When writing your review, be as specific as possible. Instead of just saying that the room was small, provide details about the size of the room, the number of furniture pieces it had, and whether or not it was comfortable for sleeping. This will give your readers a better idea of what to expect, and will also help you stand out from other reviewers who may not provide as much detail.
5. End your review with a recommendation..
Finally, end

instruction: Name the top cities in France that should not be missed. Include the best aspects of each place as well.
output:
Paris: The city of love, fashion, and culture. Paris is famous for its iconic landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, and Arc de Triomphe. It also has a vibrant food and nightlife scene, with plenty of Michelin-starred restaurants and trendy bars.
Bordeaux: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Bordeaux is known for its stunning 18th-century architecture, including the Place de la Bourse and Grand Theater. The city is also home to some of the world's best wineries and wine festivals, making it a must-visit destination for wine lovers.
Marseille: Located on the Mediterranean coast, Marseille is France's largest port city and a melting pot of cultures. Its old town, Le Panier, is filled with narrow streets, colorful houses, and historic monuments. The city is also known for its street art, beach resorts, and delicious seafood cuisine.
Lyon: Known as the gastronomic capital of France, Lyon is famous for its cuisine, particularly its renowned sausages and cheeses. The city also boasts beautiful medieval and Renaissance architecture, including the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourviere and the Gallo-Roman amphitheater.
Strasbourg: Strasbourg is the capital of the Alsace region and home to the European Parliament. The city is famous for its Christmas markets, which attract millions of visitors every year. It also has a picturesque old town, canals, and stunning cathedral.
Nice: Located on the French Riviera, Nice is known for its breathtaking beaches, luxury hotels, and glamorous atmosphere. The city is also home to the Prom

instruction: Design a programming problem related to the subject that has been given to you. Use some examples and constraints to improve your question.
output:
is a mathematical programming method to solve problems with many optimizations. Dynamic programming should be used when the value of a solution depends on the values of other solutions, rather than just one other solution. For example, how can you find the shortest path through a maze? 
To solve this problem using dynamic programming, first divide the maze into smaller sections, then for each section calculate its minimum length from all possible starting points. Finally, connect the minimum paths to find the shortest path through the maze.

instruction: The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.
input: Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine.
output: However, a zinc deficiency can lead to a weakened immune system and other health problems. Zinc is found in many foods, including red meat, poultry, seafood, nuts, beans, and whole grains. It is also available as a dietary supplement.

instruction: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it.
input:
Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.
Translate to French:
output: Dentistry is the branch of medicine that focuses on the teeth, gums and mouth. It includes the study, diagnosis, prevention, management and treatment of diseases, disorders and conditions of the mouth, mainly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. A dentist is the practitioner.

instruction: An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.
input:
The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
The invention of the compact disc (CD) in the 1980s and digital streaming and downloads in the 2000s led to a major change in how music was distributed, while the growth of social media platforms and video-sharing websites such as YouTube in the late 2000s and 2010s has helped make music promotion a global activity.

20th-century music saw a transition from an art form dominated by Western classical music and early forms of rock music to one in which many varieties of pop music predominate. This transition has also included the expansion of folk music, which had traditionally been limited to oral transmission, as well as the development of hip hop, house, and other current styles of popular music. World music is a term used to describe the diverse styles of music that were developed throughout the rest of the world, particularly in non-Western nations and their diaspora communities.

instruction: Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.
input: Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels.
output:
We are interested in seeing the main sights of Marrakech, Fes, Casablanca and the desert. We would also like to visit some riads, do a cooking class, and shop for souvenirs. The trip should be taken in May or early June. Any suggestions?
Your suggested itinerary is perfect for your needs as you will have the opportunity to discover the highlights of four major Moroccan cities, enjoy cultural experiences such as a cooking class and explore the beautiful landscapes of the Atlas Mountains. Here is a proposed itinerary for your 9-day trip:
Day 1: Arrive in Marrakech
On your first day, you will arrive in Marrakech where you will be welcomed by your local guide and driver. After picking up your bags, you will start exploring the city with a guided tour. Some highlights that you can expect to see are the Koutoubia Mosque, Jemaa el-Fnaa Square, and the Saadian Tombs. You will end the day at your riad where you will spend your first night.
Day 2: Marrakech - Agadir - Essaouira
After breakfast, you will leave Marrakech behind and head towards the coastal city of Agadir. Your next stop will be the charming seaside town of Essaouira. You will have free time to explore the town, relax on the beach, and enjoy lunch at a local restaurant. In the evening, you will return to Agadir where you will stay overnight.
Day 3: Agadir - Taroudant - Ouarzazate
In the morning, you will depart from Agadir and head towards Taroudant, a charming Berber city known for its beautiful kasbah. After having l

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output: Class Presentations can be nerve-wracking. But there are things you can do to help keep your nerves under control. First, try to relax. Take a few deep breaths and remind yourself that it’s just a presentation. Second, practice ahead of time. The more you practice, the more comfortable you will feel when it comes time to present. Finally, focus on the positive. Remember that your classmates want you to do well and are rooting for you.

instruction: Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.
input: Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
and a Piece of String
1. Gather the materials
2. Cut the beer can into two equal halves.
3. Bend the tabs on the bottom of each can so that they touch and form a loop.
4. Thread the string through this loop.
5. Attach one end of the string to something steady, such as a nail or screw.
6. Place the other end of the string in the "drum" of the can.
7. Pump the string to create suction, which will make the can move up and down.
8. Adjust the tension on the string to find the right balance between suction and movement.
9. Test your engine by pushing it along the ground.

11. Use a small motor to power your engine instead of manual labor.

instruction: Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb.

instruction: Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.
input: A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output:
Now, Zee is conducting a three-year study of 150 young adults from diverse backgrounds to further understand how light exposure at night affects their health. The research team is following the participants' sleep and circadian rhythms using wrist devices that track movement and heart rate, as well as measuring glucose levels through blood tests before and after the participants go on a weekslong "lights out" period in which they are required to keep all lights in their homes off after evening meal time.
Zee hopes to gain insights into the biological mechanisms by which light exposure is disrupting sleep and what changes occur to metabolic pathways associated with diabetes risk when people don't get enough deep sleep. She also wants to find out if improving sleep by reducing light exposure can improve health outcomes.
In addition to determining how light exposure affects the participants' health, the study will explore how socioeconomic status and neighborhood conditions play a role in how much light people are exposed to at night.
The study's participants include a mix of college students, firefighters, shift workers, parents and other individuals who do not have consistent sleep schedules. In contrast to previous studies that typically recruited older adults, Zee wanted to include younger people since hormones and physiology change with age and can impact how light exposure affects health.
Erin Hager, a 32-year old participant in the study, started the experiment last month. She has Type 1 diabetes, which requires her to monitor her blood sugar levels throughout the day and night. Her doctor recently raised her blood sugar medicine dosage, but she hasn't yet seen if the new regimen is helping with her numbers. As part of the study, Hager agreed to wear an accelerometer on

instruction: Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.
input: We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training.

instruction: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
input: Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: Moreover, we conduct a series of analyses to understand this problem better.

instruction: List the concepts that should be learned before approaching the given complex concept.
output:
Pioneer Andrew Ng Announces New Coursera AI Specialization
Andrew Ng, co-founder of Coursera and one of the leading figures in deep learning, announced a new specialization on the popular MOOC platform. The AI specialization is comprised of four courses: Building Machine Learning Systems; Natural Language Processing; Building Intelligent Bots; and Deep Learning.
The courses are designed to teach students how to develop real-world machine learning applications using open-source tools and libraries such as scikit-learn, TensorFlow, and RNNs. Students will also explore natural language processing techniques for speech recognition and chatbots, as well as learn how to build intelligent bots that can understand and interact with humans via messaging platforms like Slack and Messenger.
This specialization is ideal for anyone looking to gain hands-on experience with building machine learning applications and developing practical skills in natural language processing and intelligent bots. Whether you’re just starting out or already have some experience, this series of courses is sure to provide you with the knowledge and skills you need to succeed in the field of artificial intelligence.
